Name: AALIYAH
Meaning: Feminine form of AALI. It was popularized in the English-speaking world by the singer Aaliyah Haughton (1979-2001), who was known simply as Aaliyah.

Name: AAREN
Meaning: Variant or feminine form of AARON.

Name: AARON
Usage: English, French, German, Jewish, Biblical, Biblical Latin, Biblical Greek
Meaning: From the Hebrew name אַהֲרֹן ('Aharon), which is most likely of unknown Egyptian origin. Other theories claim a Hebrew derivation, and suggest meanings such as "high mountain" or "exalted". In the Old Testament this name is borne by the older brother of Moses. He acted as a spokesman for his brother when they appealed to the pharaoh to release the Israelites from slavery. Aaron's rod produced miracles and plagues to intimidate the pharaoh. After the departure from Egypt and arrival at Mount Sinai, God installed Aaron as the first high priest of the Israelites and promised that his descendants would form the priesthood.... [more]

Name: ABBEY
Meaning: Diminutive of ABIGAIL.

Name: ABBI
Meaning: Diminutive of ABIGAIL.

Name: ABBIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ABIGAIL.

Name: ABBY
Meaning: Diminutive of ABIGAIL.

Name: ABE (1)
Meaning: Short form of ABRAHAM.

Name: ABEGAIL
Meaning: Variant of ABIGAIL.

Name: ABEL
Usage: English, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Georgian, Biblical, Biblical Latin, Biblical Greek
Meaning: From the Hebrew name הֶבֶל (Hevel) meaning "breath". In the Old Testament he is the second son of Adam and Eve, murdered out of envy by his brother Cain. In England, this name came into use during the Middle Ages, and it was common during the Puritan era.

Name: ABIGAIL
Meaning: From the Hebrew name אֲבִיגָיִל ('Avigayil) meaning "my father is joy", derived from the roots אָב ('av) meaning "father" and גִּיל (gil) meaning "joy". In the Old Testament this is the name of Nabal's wife. After Nabal's death she became the third wife of King David.... [more]

Name: ABIGAYLE
Meaning: Variant of ABIGAIL.

Name: ABILENE
Meaning: From a place name mentioned briefly in the New Testament. It is probably from Hebrew אָבֵל ('avel) meaning "meadow, grassy area". It has occasionally been used as a given name in modern times.

Name: ABNER
Meaning: Means "my father is a light" in Hebrew, from אָב ('av) meaning "father" and נֵר (ner) meaning "lamp, light". In the Old Testament, Abner was a cousin of Saul and the commander of his army. After he killed Asahel he was himself slain by Asahel's brother Joab. It has been used as an English Christian given name since the Protestant Reformation. It was popular with the Puritans, who brought it to America in the 17th century.

Name: ABRAHAM
Usage: English, Hebrew, Spanish, French, Dutch, German, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Biblical, Biblical Latin
Meaning: This name may be viewed either as meaning "father of many" in Hebrew or else as a contraction of ABRAM (1) and הָמוֹן (hamon) meaning "many, multitude". The biblical patriarch Abraham was originally named Abram but God changed his name (see Genesis 17:5). With his father Terah, he led his wife Sarah, his nephew Lot and their other followers from Ur into Canaan. He is regarded by Jews as being the founder of the Hebrews through his son Isaac and by Muslims as being the founder of the Arabs through his son Ishmael.... [more]

Name: ABRAM (1)
Meaning: Means "high father" in Hebrew. In the Old Testament God changed Abram's name to Abraham (see Genesis 17:5).

Name: ACACIA
Meaning: From the name of a type of tree, ultimately derived from Greek ἀκή (ake) meaning "thorn, point".

Name: ACE (1)
Meaning: From the English word meaning "highest rank". More commonly a nickname, it is occasionally used as a given name.

Name: ADA
Usage: English, German, Polish, Hungarian, Italian, Finnish, Ancient Germanic
Meaning: Originally a short form of Germanic names such as ADELAIDE or ADELINA that begin with the element adal meaning "noble". This name was borne by Augusta Ada King (1815-1852), the Countess of Lovelace (known as Ada Lovelace), a daughter of Lord Byron. She was an assistant to Charles Babbage, the inventor of an early mechanical computer.

Name: ADAIR
Meaning: From an English surname that was derived from the given name EDGAR.

Name: ADALINE
Meaning: Variant of ADELINA.

Name: ADALYN
Meaning: Variant of ADELINE using the popular name suffix lyn.

Name: ADALYNN
Meaning: Variant of ADELINE using the popular name suffix lynn.

Name: ADAM
Usage: English, French, German, Polish, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Czech, Slovak, Russian, Ukrainian, Croatian, Serbian, Macedonian, Romanian, Catalan, Hebrew, Arabic, Georgian, Biblical, Biblical Latin, Biblical Greek, Biblical Hebrew
Meaning: This is the Hebrew word for "man". It could be ultimately derived from Hebrew אדם ('adam) meaning "to be red", referring to the ruddy colour of human skin, or from Akkadian adamu meaning "to make".... [more]

Name: ADAMINA
Meaning: Feminine form of ADAM.

Name: ADDIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ADELAIDE, ADELINE, ADDISON or other names containing the same sound.

Name: ADDILYN
Meaning: Variant of ADELINE using the popular name suffix lyn.

Name: ADDISON
Meaning: From an English surname meaning "son of ADAM". Its recent popularity as a feminine name stems from its similarity in sound to Madison.

Name: ADDY (1)
Meaning: Diminutive of ADELAIDE, ADELINE, ADDISON or other names containing the same sound.

Name: ADDYSON
Meaning: Feminine variant of ADDISON.

Name: ADELA
Usage: English, Spanish, Romanian, Polish, Slovak, Ancient Germanic
Meaning: Originally a short form of names beginning with the Germanic element adal meaning "noble". Saint Adela was a 7th-century Frankish princess who founded a monastery at Pfazel in France. This name was also borne by a daughter of William the Conqueror.

Name: ADELAIDE
Meaning: Means "noble type", from the French form of the Germanic name Adalheidis, which was composed of the elements adal "noble" and heid "kind, sort, type". It was borne in the 10th century by Saint Adelaide, the wife of the Holy Roman emperor Otto the Great. In Britain the parallel form Alice, derived via Old French, has historically been more common, though this form did gain some currency in the 19th century due to the popularity of the German-born wife of King William IV, for whom the city of Adelaide in Australia was named in 1836.

Name: ADELE
Meaning: Form of ADELA used in several languages.

Name: ADELIA
Meaning: Elaborated form of ADELA.

Name: ADELINE
Meaning: French and English form of ADELINA.

Name: ADELLA
Meaning: Variant of ADELA.

Name: ADELLE
Meaning: Variant of ADELE.

Name: ADELYN
Meaning: Variant of ADELINE using the popular name suffix lyn.

Name: ADELYNN
Meaning: Variant of ADELINE using the popular name suffix lynn.

Name: ADEN
Meaning: Variant of AIDAN.

Name: ADENA
Meaning: Possibly a variant of ADINA (1).

Name: ADOLPH
Meaning: English form of ADOLF, rarely used since World War II.

Name: ADRIA
Meaning: Short form of ADRIANA.

Name: ADRIAN
Usage: English, Romanian, Polish, German, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Russian
Meaning: Form of Hadrianus (see HADRIAN) used in several languages. Several saints and six popes have borne this name, including the only English pope, Adrian IV, and the only Dutch pope, Adrian VI. As an English name, it has been in use since the Middle Ages, though it was not popular until modern times.

Name: ADRIANA
Usage: Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Romanian, Polish, Slovak, Czech, English, Dutch
Meaning: Feminine form of ADRIAN.

Name: ADRIANNA
Meaning: Feminine form of ADRIAN.

Name: ADRIANNE
Meaning: Feminine form of ADRIAN.

Name: ADRIENNE
Meaning: French feminine form of ADRIAN.

Name: AGATHA
Meaning: Latinized form of the Greek name Ἀγαθή (Agathe), derived from Greek ἀγαθός (agathos) meaning "good". Saint Agatha was a 3rd-century martyr from Sicily who was tortured and killed after spurning the advances of a Roman official. The saint was widely revered in the Middle Ages, and her name has been used throughout Christian Europe (in various spellings). The mystery writer Agatha Christie (1890-1976) was a famous modern bearer of this name.

Name: AGGIE
Meaning: Diminutive of AGNES or AGATHA.

Name: AGNES
Usage: English, German, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Icelandic, Estonian, Ancient Greek (Latinized)
Meaning: Latinized form of the Greek name Ἁγνή (Hagne), derived from Greek ἁγνός (hagnos) meaning "chaste". Saint Agnes was a virgin martyred during the persecutions of the Roman emperor Diocletian. The name became associated with Latin agnus "lamb", resulting in the saint's frequent depiction with a lamb by her side. Due to her renown, the name became common in Christian Europe.... [more]

Name: AIDAN
Meaning: Anglicized form of AODHÁN. In the latter part of the 20th century it became popular in America due to its sound, since it uses the same fashionable den suffix sound found in such names as Braden and Hayden.

Name: AIDEN
Meaning: Variant of AIDAN.

Name: AILEEN
Meaning: Variant of EILEEN.

Name: AIMEE
Meaning: Variant of AMY, influenced by French AIMÉE.

Name: AINSLEE
Meaning: Variant of AINSLEY.

Name: AINSLEY
Meaning: From a surname that was from a place name: either Annesley in Nottinghamshire or Ansley in Warwickshire. The place names themselves derive from Old English anne "alone, solitary" or ansetl "hermitage" and leah "woodland, clearing".

Name: AINSLIE
Meaning: Variant of AINSLEY.

Name: AL
Meaning: Short form of ALBERT and other names beginning with Al. A notable bearer is American actor Al Pacino (1940-).

Name: ALAINA
Meaning: Variant of ALANA, probably influenced by ELAINE.

Name: ALAIYA
Meaning: Variant of AALIYAH.

Name: ALAN
Meaning: The meaning of this name is not known for certain. It was used in Brittany at least as early as the 6th century, and it possibly means either "little rock" or "handsome" in Breton. Alternatively, it may derive from the tribal name of the Alans, an Iranian people who migrated into Europe in the 4th and 5th centuries.... [more]

Name: ALANA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALAN.

Name: ALANI
Meaning: Possibly a variant of ALANA, or possibly from Hawaiian ʻalani meaning "orange (tree or fruit)".

Name: ALANIS
Meaning: Feminine form of ALAN. Canadian musician Alanis Morissette (1974-) was named after her father Alan. Her parents apparently decided to use this particular spelling after seeing this word in a Greek newspaper.

Name: ALANNA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALAN.

Name: ALANNAH
Meaning: Variant of ALANA. It has been influenced by the affectionate Anglo-Irish word alannah, from the Irish Gaelic phrase a leanbh meaning "O child".

Name: ALANNIS
Meaning: Variant of ALANIS.

Name: ALAYA
Meaning: Variant of AALIYAH.

Name: ALAYAH
Meaning: Variant of AALIYAH.

Name: ALAYNA
Meaning: Variant of ALAINA.

Name: ALBAN
Meaning: From the Roman cognomen Albanus, which meant "from Alba". Alba (from Latin albus "white") was the name of various places within the Roman Empire, including the city Alba Longa. This name was borne by Saint Alban, the first British martyr (4th century). According to tradition, he sheltered a fugitive priest in his house. When his house was searched, he disguised himself as the priest, was arrested in his stead, and was beheaded. As an English name, Alban was occasionally used in the Middle Ages and was revived in the 18th century, though it is now uncommon.

Name: ALBERT
Usage: English, French, Catalan, German, Polish, Russian, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Icelandic, Romanian, Hungarian, Ancient Germanic
Meaning: From the Germanic name Adalbert meaning "noble and bright", composed of the elements adal "noble" and beraht "bright". This name was common among medieval German royalty. The Normans introduced it to England, where it replaced the Old English cognate Æðelberht. Though it became rare in England by the 17th century, it was repopularized in the 19th century by the German-born Prince Albert, the husband of Queen Victoria.... [more]

Name: ALBERTA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALBERT. This is the name of a Canadian province, which was named in honour of a daughter of Queen Victoria.

Name: ALBIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ALBERT.

Name: ALBIN
Meaning: Form of ALBINUS in several languages.

Name: ALDEN
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from the Old English given name EALDWINE.

Name: ALDOUS
Meaning: Probably a diminutive of names beginning with the Old English element eald "old". It has been in use as an English given name since the Middle Ages, mainly in East Anglia. The British author Aldous Huxley (1894-1963) was a famous bearer of this name.

Name: ALEA
Meaning: Variant of AALIYAH.

Name: ALEAH
Meaning: Variant of AALIYAH.

Name: ALEASE
Meaning: Possibly a variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALEC
Meaning: Short form of ALEXANDER.

Name: ALECIA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALEESHA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALENE
Meaning: Variant of ALINE.

Name: ALESHA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALESIA
Meaning: Possibly a variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALETA
Meaning: Possibly a variant of ALETHEA. This was the name of the wife of the title character in the comic strip Prince Valiant, which first appeared in 1937.

Name: ALETHA
Meaning: Variant of ALETHEA.

Name: ALETHEA
Meaning: Derived from Greek ἀλήθεια (aletheia) meaning "truth". This name was coined in the 16th century.

Name: ALEX
Usage: English, Dutch, German, French, Portuguese, Italian, Romanian, Greek, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Icelandic, Hungarian, Czech, Russian
Meaning: Short form of ALEXANDER, ALEXANDRA, and other names beginning with Alex.

Name: ALEXA
Meaning: Short form of ALEXANDRA.

Name: ALEXANDER
Usage: English, German, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Icelandic, Hungarian, Slovak, Biblical, Ancient Greek (Latinized), Greek Mythology (Latinized)
Meaning: Latinized form of the Greek name Ἀλέξανδρος (Alexandros), which meant "defending men" from Greek ἀλέξω (alexo) meaning "to defend, help" and ἀνήρ (aner) meaning "man" (genitive ἀνδρός). In Greek mythology this was another name of the hero Paris, and it also belongs to several characters in the New Testament. However, the most famous bearer was Alexander the Great, king of Macedon. In the 4th century BC he built a huge empire out of Greece, Egypt, Persia, and parts of India. Due to his fame, and later medieval tales involving him, use of his name spread throughout Europe.... [more]

Name: ALEXANDRA
Usage: English, German, Dutch, French, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Icelandic, Greek, Portuguese, Romanian, Czech, Slovak, Hungarian, Catalan, Spanish, Italian, Russian, Ukrainian, Ancient Greek, Greek Mythology
Meaning: Feminine form of ALEXANDER. In Greek mythology this was a Mycenaean epithet of the goddess Hera, and an alternate name of Cassandra. It was borne by several early Christian saints, and also by the wife of Nicholas II, the last czar of Russia. She was from Germany and had the birth name Alix, but was renamed Александра (Aleksandra) upon joining the Russian Church.

Name: ALEXANDREA
Meaning: Variant of ALEXANDRIA.

Name: ALEXANDRIA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALEXANDER. Alexander the Great founded several cities by this name (or renamed them) as he extended his empire eastward. The most notable of these is Alexandria in Egypt, founded by Alexander in 331 BC.

Name: ALEXANDRINA
Meaning: Elaborated form of ALEXANDRA. This was the first name of Queen Victoria; her middle name was Victoria.

Name: ALEXIA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALEXIS.

Name: ALEXINA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALEX, or a diminutive of ALEXIS.

Name: ALEXIS
Usage: German, French, English, Greek, Ancient Greek
Meaning: From the Greek name Ἄλεξις (Alexis) meaning "helper" or "defender", derived from Greek ἀλέξω (alexo) meaning "to defend, to help". This was the name of a 3rd-century BC Greek comic poet, and also of several saints. It is used somewhat interchangeably with the related name Ἀλέξιος or Alexius, borne by five Byzantine emperors. In the English-speaking world it is more commonly used as a feminine name.

Name: ALEXUS
Meaning: Variant of ALEXIS.

Name: ALF (2)
Meaning: Short form of ALFRED.

Name: ALFIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ALFRED.

Name: ALFRED
Usage: English, French, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, German, Polish, Dutch
Meaning: Means "elf counsel", derived from the Old English name Ælfræd, composed of the elements ælf "elf" and ræd "counsel". Alfred the Great was a 9th-century king of Wessex who fought unceasingly against the Danes living in northeast England. He was also a scholar, and he translated many Latin books into Old English. His fame helped to ensure the usage of this name even after the Norman Conquest, when most Old English names were replaced by Norman ones. It became rare by the end of the Middle Ages, but was revived in the 18th century.... [more]

Name: ALFREDA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALFRED.

Name: ALGAR
Meaning: Means "elf spear" from Old English ælf "elf" and gar "spear". This Old English name was rarely used after the Norman Conquest, being absorbed by similar-sounding names and Norman and Scandinavian cognates. It was briefly revived in the 19th century.

Name: ALGER
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from the given name ALGAR.

Name: ALGERNON
Meaning: Originally a Norman French nickname, derived from aux gernons "having a moustache", which was applied to William de Percy, a companion of William the Conqueror. It was first used a given name in the 15th century (for a descendant of William de Percy).

Name: ALI (2)
Meaning: Diminutive of ALISON, ALEXANDRA or other names beginning with the same sound.

Name: ALIAH
Meaning: Variant of AALIYAH.

Name: ALICE
Usage: English, French, Portuguese, Italian, German, Czech
Meaning: From the Old French name Aalis, a short form of Adelais, itself a short form of the Germanic name Adalheidis (see ADELAIDE). This name became popular in France and England in the 12th century. It was among the most common names in England until the 16th century, when it began to decline. It was revived in the 19th century.... [more]

Name: ALICIA
Meaning: Latinized form of ALICE.

Name: ALINE
Meaning: Medieval short form of ADELINE. As an English name, in modern times it has sometimes been regarded as a variant of EILEEN. This was the name of a popular 1965 song by the French singer Christophe.

Name: ALISE (2)
Meaning: Variant of ALICE.

Name: ALISHA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALISHIA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALISIA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALISON
Meaning: Norman French diminutive of Aalis (see ALICE). It was common in England, Scotland and France in the Middle Ages, and was later revived in England in the 20th century via Scotland. Unlike most other English names ending in son, it is not derived from a surname.

Name: ALISSA
Meaning: Variant of ALYSSA.

Name: ALISYA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALITA
Meaning: Possibly a variant of ALETHEA.

Name: ALIVIA
Meaning: Variant of OLIVIA.

Name: ALLAN
Meaning: Variant of ALAN. The American author Edgar Allan Poe (1809-1849) got his middle name from the surname of the parents who adopted him.

Name: ALLANA
Meaning: Variant of ALANA.

Name: ALLANNAH
Meaning: Variant of ALANNAH.

Name: ALLEGRA
Meaning: Means "cheerful, lively" in Italian. It was borne by a short-lived illegitimate daughter of Lord Byron (1817-1822).

Name: ALLEN
Meaning: Variant of ALAN. A famous bearer of this name was Allen Ginsberg (1926-1997), an American beat poet. Another is the American film director and actor Woody Allen (1935-), who took the stage name Allen from his real first name.

Name: ALLIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ALISON, ALEXANDRA and other names beginning with the same sound.

Name: ALLISON
Meaning: From the middle of the 20th century this has primarily been used as a variant of the feminine name ALISON. However, prior to that it was used as an uncommon masculine name, derived from the English and Scottish surname ALLISON.

Name: ALLISSA
Meaning: Variant of ALYSSA.

Name: ALLY (1)
Meaning: Diminutive of ALISON, ALEXANDRA and other names beginning with the same sound.

Name: ALLYCIA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALLYN
Meaning: Variant or feminine form of ALAN.

Name: ALLYSON
Meaning: Variant of ALISON.

Name: ALMA (1)
Meaning: This name became popular after the Battle of Alma (1854), which took place near the River Alma in Crimea and ended in a victory for Britain and France. However, the name was in rare use before the battle; it was probably inspired by Latin almus "nourishing". It also coincides with the Spanish word meaning "the soul".

Name: ALOYSIUS
Meaning: Latinized form of Aloys, an old Occitan form of LOUIS. This was the name of a 16th-century Italian saint, Aloysius Gonzaga. The name has been in occasional use among Catholics since his time.

Name: ALPHA
Meaning: From the name of the first letter in the Greek alphabet, Α.

Name: ALPHONSO
Meaning: Variant of ALFONSO.

Name: ALPHONZO
Meaning: Uncommon variant of ALFONSO.

Name: ALTON
Meaning: From an Old English surname that was derived from a place name meaning "town at the source of the river".

Name: ALVA (2)
Meaning: Variant of ALVAH. A famous bearer of this name was the inventor Thomas Alva Edison (1847-1931).

Name: ALVENA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALVIN.

Name: ALVIN
Meaning: From a medieval form of any of the Old English names ÆLFWINE, ÆÐELWINE or EALDWINE. It was revived in the 19th century, in part from a surname that was derived from the Old English names. As a Scandinavian name it is derived from Alfvin, an Old Norse cognate of Ælfwine.

Name: ALVINA
Meaning: Feminine form of ALVIN.

Name: ALYCE
Meaning: Variant of ALICE.

Name: ALYCIA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALYS
Meaning: Variant of ALICE.

Name: ALYSA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALYSE
Meaning: Variant of ALICE.

Name: ALYSHA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALYSIA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALYSON
Meaning: Variant of ALISON.

Name: ALYSSA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA. The spelling has probably been influenced by that of the alyssum flower, the name of which is derived from Greek ἀ (a), a negative prefix, combined with λύσσα (lyssa) meaning "madness, rabies", since it was believed to cure madness.

Name: ALYSSIA
Meaning: Variant of ALICIA.

Name: ALYX
Meaning: Feminine variant of ALEX.

Name: AMABEL
Meaning: Medieval feminine form of AMABILIS.

Name: AMANDA
Usage: English, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Late Roman
Meaning: In part this is a feminine form of AMANDUS. However, it was not used during the Middle Ages. In the 17th century it was recreated by authors and poets who based it directly on Latin amanda meaning "lovable, worthy of love". Notably, the playwright Colley Cibber used it for a character in his play Love's Last Shift (1696). It came into regular use during the 19th century.

Name: AMBER
Meaning: From the English word amber that denotes either the gemstone, which is formed from fossil resin, or the orange-yellow colour. The word ultimately derives from Arabic عنبر ('anbar). It began to be used as a given name in the late 19th century, but it only became popular after the release of Kathleen Winsor's novel Forever Amber (1944).

Name: AMBERLY
Meaning: Elaboration of AMBER, influenced by the spelling of the name KIMBERLY.

Name: AMBERLYNN
Meaning: Elaboration of AMBER using the popular name suffix lyn.

Name: AMBROSE
Meaning: From the Late Latin name Ambrosius, which was derived from the Greek name Ἀμβρόσιος (Ambrosios) meaning "immortal". Saint Ambrose was a 4th-century theologian and bishop of Milan, who is considered a Doctor of the Church. Due to the saint, the name came into general use in Christian Europe, though it was never particularly common in England.

Name: AMBROSINE
Meaning: Feminine form of AMBROSE.

Name: AMELIA
Usage: English, Spanish, Italian, Polish, Dutch, German, Ancient Germanic
Meaning: Variant of AMALIA, though it is sometimes confused with EMILIA, which has a different origin. The name became popular in England after the German House of Hanover came to the British throne in the 18th century - it was borne by daughters of both George II and George III. The author Henry Fielding used it for the title character in his novel Amelia (1751). Another famous bearer was Amelia Earhart (1897-1937), the first woman to make a solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean.... [more]

Name: AMERICA
Meaning: In the English-speaking world, this name is usually given in reference to the United States of America (see AMERIGO). It came into use as an American name in the 19th century.

Name: AMERY
Meaning: Variant of EMERY.

Name: AMETHYST
Meaning: From the name of the purple semi-precious stone, which is derived from the Greek negative prefix ἀ (a) and μέθυστος (methystos) meaning "intoxicated, drunk", as it was believed to be a remedy against drunkenness.

Name: AMI (2)
Meaning: Variant of AMY.

Name: AMIAS
Meaning: Variant of AMYAS.

Name: AMIE
Meaning: Variant of AMY.

Name: AMILIA
Meaning: Variant of either AMALIA or EMILIA.

Name: AMITY
Meaning: From the English word meaning "friendship", ultimately deriving from Latin amicitia.

Name: AMOS
Usage: English, Hebrew, Biblical, Biblical Latin, Biblical Greek, Biblical Hebrew
Meaning: From Hebrew עָמַס ('amas) meaning "load, burden". Amos is one of the twelve minor prophets of the Old Testament, the author of the Book of Amos, which speaks against greed, corruption and oppression of the poor. Written about the 8th century BC, it is among the oldest of the prophetic books. As an English name, Amos has been used since the Protestant Reformation, and was popular among the Puritans.

Name: AMY
Meaning: English form of the Old French name Amée meaning "beloved" (modern French aimée), a vernacular form of the Latin Amata. As an English name, it was in use in the Middle Ages (though not common) and was revived in the 19th century.

Name: AMYAS
Meaning: Meaning unknown, perhaps a derivative of AMIS. Alternatively, it may come from a surname that originally indicated that the bearer was from the city of Amiens in France. Edmund Spenser used this name for a minor character in his epic poem The Faerie Queene (1590).

Name: ANABELLA
Meaning: Variant of ANNABEL.

Name: ANABELLE
Meaning: Variant of ANNABEL.

Name: ANASTASIA
Usage: Greek, Russian, Ukrainian, Belarusian, English, Spanish, Italian, Georgian, Ancient Greek
Meaning: Feminine form of ANASTASIUS. This was the name of a 4th-century Dalmatian saint who was martyred during the persecutions of the Roman emperor Diocletian. Due to her, the name has been common in Eastern Orthodox Christianity (in various spellings). As an English name it has been in use since the Middle Ages. A famous bearer was the youngest daughter of the last Russian tsar Nicholas II, who was rumoured to have escaped the execution of her family in 1918.

Name: ANAYA
Meaning: Variant of ANIYA.

Name: ANDERSON
Meaning: From a surname meaning "son of ANDREW".

Name: ANDI
Meaning: Diminutive of ANDREA (2).

Name: ANDIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ANDREW or ANDREA (2).

Name: ANDRE
Meaning: English form of ANDRÉ.

Name: ANDREA (2)
Usage: English, German, Spanish, Czech, Slovak, Hungarian, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Icelandic, Dutch, Croatian, Serbian
Meaning: Feminine form of ANDREW. As an English name, it has been used since the 17th century, though it was not common until the 20th century.

Name: ANDREW
Meaning: English form of the Greek name Ἀνδρέας (Andreas), which was derived from ἀνδρεῖος (andreios) meaning "manly, masculine", a derivative of ἀνήρ (aner) meaning "man". In the New Testament the apostle Andrew, the first disciple to join Jesus, is the brother of Simon Peter. According to tradition, he later preached in the Black Sea region, with some legends saying he was crucified on an X-shaped cross. Andrew, being a Greek name, was probably only a nickname or a translation of his real Hebrew name, which is not known.... [more]

Name: ANDRINA
Meaning: Feminine form of ANDREW.

Name: ANDY
Meaning: Diminutive of ANDREW or sometimes ANDREA (2). American pop artist and filmmaker Andy Warhol (1928-1987) was a famous bearer of this name.

Name: ANEMONE
Meaning: From the name of the anemone flower, which is derived from Greek ἄνεμος (anemos) meaning "wind".

Name: ANGEL
Meaning: From the medieval Latin masculine name Angelus, which was derived from the name of the heavenly creature (itself derived from the Greek word ἄγγελος (angelos) meaning "messenger"). It has never been very common in the English-speaking world, where it is sometimes used as a feminine name in modern times.

Name: ANGELA
Usage: English, Italian, German, Dutch, Romanian, Slovene, Slovak, Russian, Macedonian, Late Roman
Meaning: Feminine form of Angelus (see ANGEL). As an English name, it came into use in the 18th century.

Name: ANGELIA
Meaning: Elaborated form of ANGELA.

Name: ANGELICA
Meaning: Derived from Latin angelicus meaning "angelic", ultimately related to Greek ἄγγελος (angelos) meaning "messenger". The poets Boiardo and Ariosto used this name in their Orlando poems (1483 and 1532), where it belongs to Orlando's love interest. It has been used as a given name since the 18th century.

Name: ANGELINA
Usage: Italian, English, Russian, German, Dutch, Spanish, Portuguese, Greek
Meaning: Latinate diminutive of ANGELA. A famous bearer is American actress Angelina Jolie (1975-).

Name: ANGELLE
Meaning: Feminine variant of ANGEL.

Name: ANGIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ANGELA.

Name: ANGUS
Meaning: Anglicized form of AONGHUS.

Name: ANIMA (2)
Meaning: Means "soul, spirit" in Latin. In Jungian psychology the anima is an individual's true inner self, or soul.

Name: ANISE
Meaning: From the English word for the herb, also called aniseed.

Name: ANISSA
Meaning: This name was first brought to public attention in 1966 by the child actress Anissa Jones (1958-1976). In her case it was a transcription of the Arabic name أنيسة (see ANISA), given to honour her Lebanese heritage. Other parents who have since used this name may view it simply as an elaboration of ANNA using the popular name suffix issa.

Name: ANITA (1)
Usage: Spanish, Portuguese, Croatian, Slovene, English, Dutch, German, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Finnish, Polish, Latvian
Meaning: Spanish, Portuguese, Croatian and Slovene diminutive of ANA.

Name: ANIYA
Meaning: Modern name, possibly based on ANYA or AALIYAH.

Name: ANIYAH
Meaning: Variant of ANIYA.

Name: ANJELICA
Meaning: Variant of ANGELICA.

Name: ANN
Meaning: English and Manx form of ANNE (1). In the English-speaking world, both this spelling and Anne have been used since the late Middle Ages. Currently Ann is less popular than Anne (and both are less popular than their relatives Anna and Hannah).

Name: ANNA
Usage: English, Italian, German, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Finnish, Estonian, Latvian, Greek, Hungarian, Polish, Russian, Ukrainian, Belarusian, Czech, Slovak, Bulgarian, Icelandic, Faroese, Catalan, Occitan, Breton, Biblical, Old Church Slavic, Biblical Latin, Biblical Greek
Meaning: Form of Channah (see HANNAH) used in the Greek and Latin Old Testament. Many later Old Testament translations, including the English, use the Hannah spelling instead of Anna. The name appears briefly in the New Testament belonging to a prophetess who recognized Jesus as the Messiah. It was a popular name in the Byzantine Empire from an early date, and in the Middle Ages it became common among Western Christians due to veneration of Saint Anna (usually known as Saint Anne in English), the name traditionally assigned to the mother of the Virgin Mary.... [more]

Name: ANNABEL
Meaning: Variant of AMABEL influenced by the name ANNA. This name appears to have arisen in Scotland in the Middle Ages.

Name: ANNABELLA
Meaning: Latinate form of ANNABEL. It can also be taken as a combination of ANNA and BELLA.

Name: ANNABELLE
Meaning: Variant of ANNABEL. It can also be taken as a combination of ANNA and BELLE.

Name: ANNABETH
Meaning: Combination of ANNA and BETH.

Name: ANNALEE
Meaning: Combination of ANNA and LEE.

Name: ANNALISE
Meaning: Combination of ANNA and LISE.

Name: ANNE (1)
Usage: French, English, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Finnish, Estonian, German, Dutch, Basque
Meaning: French form of ANNA. It was imported to England in the 13th century, but it did not become popular until three centuries later. The spelling variant Ann was also commonly found from this period, and is still used to this day.... [more]

Name: ANNEKA
Meaning: Variant of ANNIKA.

Name: ANNETTE
Usage: French, English, German, Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, Dutch
Meaning: French diminutive of ANNE (1). It has also been widely used in the English-speaking world, and it became popular in America in the late 1950s due to the fame of actress Annette Funicello (1942-).

Name: ANNICE
Meaning: Variant of ANNIS.

Name: ANNIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ANNE (1).

Name: ANNIKA
Usage: Swedish, Dutch, Finnish, Estonian, German, English (Modern)
Meaning: Swedish diminutive of ANNA.

Name: ANNIS
Meaning: Medieval English form of AGNES.

Name: ANNMARIE
Meaning: Combination of ANN and MARIE.

Name: ANNORA
Meaning: Medieval English variant of HONORA.

Name: ANONA
Meaning: Meaning unknown. It was possibly inspired by an American song by this name written by Vivian Grey in 1903 and recorded by musician Vess Ossman. The lyrics tell of a Native American woman named Anona from Arizona.

Name: ANSEL
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from the given name ANSELM. A famous bearer was American photographer Ansel Adams (1902-1984).

Name: ANSELM
Meaning: Derived from the Germanic elements ans "god" and helm "helmet, protection". This name was brought to England in the late 11th century by Saint Anselm, who was born in northern Italy. He was archbishop of Canterbury and a Doctor of the Church.

Name: ANSLEY
Meaning: Variant of AINSLEY.

Name: ANSON
Meaning: From a surname meaning "son of AGNES".

Name: ANTHONY
Meaning: English form of the Roman family name Antonius, which is of unknown Etruscan origin. The most notable member of the Roman family was the general Marcus Antonius (called Mark Antony in English), who for a period in the 1st century BC ruled the Roman Empire jointly with Augustus. When their relationship turned sour, he and his mistress Cleopatra were attacked and forced to commit suicide, as related in Shakespeare's tragedy Antony and Cleopatra (1606).... [more]

Name: ANTON
Usage: German, Russian, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Icelandic, Dutch, Bulgarian, Ukrainian, Belarusian, Slovene, Slovak, Macedonian, Croatian, Romanian, Estonian, Finnish, English
Meaning: Form of Antonius (see ANTHONY) used in various languages.

Name: ANTONETTE
Meaning: Diminutive of ANTONIA.

Name: ANTONIA
Usage: Italian, Spanish, English, German, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Dutch, Romanian, Greek, Croatian, Bulgarian, Ancient Roman
Meaning: Feminine form of Antonius (see ANTHONY).

Name: ANTONY
Meaning: Variant of ANTHONY. This was formerly the usual English spelling of the name, but during the 17th century the h began to be added.

Name: APRIL
Meaning: From the name of the month, probably originally derived from Latin aperire "to open", referring to the opening of flowers. It has only been commonly used as a given name since the 1940s.

Name: ARABELLA
Meaning: Medieval Scottish name, probably a variant of ANNABEL. It has long been associated with Latin orabilis meaning "invokable, yielding to prayer".

Name: ARAMINTA
Meaning: Meaning unknown. This name was (first?) used by William Congreve in his comedy The Old Bachelor (1693) and later by Sir John Vanbrugh in his comedy The Confederacy (1705). This was the real name of abolitionist Harriet Tubman (1820-1913), who was born Araminta Ross.

Name: ARCHER
Meaning: From an English surname meaning "bowman, archer", of Old French origin.

Name: ARCHIBALD
Meaning: Derived from the Germanic elements ercan "genuine" and bald "bold". The first element was altered due to the influence of Greek names beginning with the element ἀρχός (archos) meaning "master". The Normans brought this name to England. It first became common in Scotland in the Middle Ages.

Name: ARCHIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ARCHIBALD. This name is borne by Archie Andrews, an American comic-book character created in 1941.

Name: ARDATH
Meaning: From the name of a plain that appears in the apocryphal book of 2 Esdras (verse 9:26) in some versions of the Old Testament. This place name was used by Marie Corelli for the title of an 1889 novel, which is probably the reason it gained some currency as a given name just after this time.

Name: ARDEN
Meaning: From an English surname, originally taken from various place names, which were derived from a Celtic word meaning "high".

Name: ARDITH
Meaning: Variant of ARDATH.

Name: ARETHA
Meaning: Possibly derived from Greek ἀρετή (arete) meaning "virtue". This name was popularized in the 1960s by American singer Aretha Franklin (1942-).

Name: ARIA (1)
Meaning: Means "song, melody" in Italian (literally means "air"). An aria is an elaborate vocal solo, the type usually performed in operas. As an English name, it has only been in use since the 20th century. It is not common in Italy.

Name: ARIAH
Meaning: Variant of ARIA (1).

Name: ARIANA
Meaning: Portuguese form of ARIADNE.

Name: ARIANNA
Meaning: Italian form of ARIADNE.

Name: ARIC
Meaning: Variant of ERIC.

Name: ARIEL
Usage: Hebrew, English, French, Spanish, Biblical, Biblical Greek
Meaning: Means "lion of God" in Hebrew, from אֲרִי ('ari) meaning "lion" and אֵל ('el) meaning "God". In the Old Testament it is used as another name for the city of Jerusalem. Shakespeare used it as the name of a spirit in his play The Tempest (1611), and one of the moons of Uranus bears this name in his honour. As an English name, it became more common for females in the 1980s, especially after it was used for the title character in the Disney film The Little Mermaid (1989).

Name: ARIELLA
Meaning: Strictly feminine form of ARIEL.

Name: ARIENNE
Meaning: Variant of ARIANE.

Name: ARIN
Meaning: Variant of ERIN or AARON.

Name: ARIYAH
Meaning: Variant of ARIA (1).

Name: ARLEEN
Meaning: Variant of ARLINE.

Name: ARLEN
Meaning: Meaning unknown, possibly from a surname.

Name: ARLENE
Meaning: Variant of ARLINE.

Name: ARLIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ARLINE and other names beginning with Arl.

Name: ARLINE
Meaning: Meaning unknown, possibly invented by Michael William Balfe for the main character in his opera The Bohemian Girl (1843).

Name: ARLO
Meaning: Meaning uncertain. It was perhaps inspired by the fictional place name Arlo Hill from the poem The Faerie Queene (1590) by Edmund Spenser. Spenser probably got Arlo by altering the real Irish place name Aherlow, which is Gaelic meaning "between two highlands".

Name: ARN
Meaning: Short form of ARNOLD.

Name: ARNIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ARNOLD.

Name: ARNOLD
Usage: English, German, Dutch, Polish, Ancient Germanic
Meaning: From a Germanic name meaning "eagle power", derived from the elements arn "eagle" and wald "power". The Normans brought it to England, where it replaced the Old English cognate Earnweald. It died out as an English name after the Middle Ages, but it was revived in the 19th century.... [more]

Name: ARRON
Meaning: Variant of AARON.

Name: ART
Meaning: Short form of ARTHUR.

Name: ARTHUR
Usage: English, French, German, Dutch, Norwegian, Danish, Swedish, Welsh Mythology, Arthurian Romance
Meaning: The meaning of this name is unknown. It could be derived from the Celtic elements artos "bear" combined with viros "man" or rigos "king". Alternatively it could be related to an obscure Roman family name Artorius.... [more]

Name: ARTIE
Meaning: Diminutive and feminine form of ARTHUR.

Name: ARVEL
Meaning: Meaning unknown, possibly a variant of ARWEL.

Name: ARYANA
Meaning: Variant of ARIANA.

Name: ASH
Meaning: Short form of ASHLEY. It can also come directly from the English word denoting either the tree or the residue of fire.

Name: ASHER
Meaning: Means "happy, blessed" in Hebrew. Asher in the Old Testament is a son of Jacob by Leah's handmaid Zilpah, and the ancestor of one of the twelve tribes of Israel. The meaning of his name is explained in Genesis 30:13.

Name: ASHLEA
Meaning: Feminine variant of ASHLEY.

Name: ASHLEE
Meaning: Feminine variant of ASHLEY.

Name: ASHLEIGH
Meaning: Feminine variant of ASHLEY.

Name: ASHLEY
Meaning: From an English surname that was originally derived from place names meaning "ash tree clearing", from a combination of Old English æsc and leah. Until the 1960s it was more commonly given to boys in the United States, but it is now most often used on girls. It reached its height of popularity in America in 1987, but it did not become the highest ranked name until 1991, being overshadowed by the likewise-popular Jessica until then. In the United Kingdom it is still more common as a masculine name.

Name: ASHLIE
Meaning: Feminine variant of ASHLEY.

Name: ASHLYN
Meaning: Combination of ASHLEY and the popular name suffix lyn.

Name: ASHLYNN
Meaning: Variant of ASHLYN.

Name: ASHTON
Meaning: From a surname that was originally derived from a place name that meant "ash tree town" in Old English.

Name: ASIA (1)
Meaning: From the name of the continent, which is perhaps derived from Akkadian asu, meaning "east".

Name: ASPEN
Meaning: From the English word for the tree, derived from Old English æspe. It is also the name of a ski resort in Colorado.

Name: ASTER
Meaning: From the name of the flower, which is derived via Latin from Greek ἀστήρ (aster) meaning "star".

Name: ASTON
Meaning: From a surname that was originally derived from either a place name meaning "east town" in Old English or from the given name ÆÐELSTAN.

Name: ASTOR
Meaning: From a surname derived from Occitan astur meaning "hawk".

Name: ASTRA
Meaning: Means "star", ultimately from Greek ἀστήρ (aster). This name has only been (rarely) used since the 20th century.

Name: ATHELSTAN
Meaning: Modern form of ÆÐELSTAN. This name was revived in Britain the latter half of the 19th century.

Name: ATHENA
Meaning: Meaning unknown. Athena was the Greek goddess of wisdom and warfare and the patron goddess of the city of Athens in Greece. It is likely that her name is derived from that of the city, not vice versa. The earliest mention of her seems to be a 15th-century BC Mycenaean Greek inscription from Knossos on Crete.... [more]

Name: AUBERON
Meaning: Norman French derivative of a Germanic name, probably ALBERICH.

Name: AUBREE
Meaning: Feminine variant of AUBREY.

Name: AUBREY
Meaning: Norman French form of the Germanic name ALBERICH. As an English masculine name it was common in the Middle Ages, and was revived in the 19th century. Since the mid-1970s it has more frequently been given to girls, due to Bread's 1972 song Aubrey along with its similarity to the established feminine name Audrey.

Name: AUBRIE
Meaning: Variant of AUBREY.

Name: AUDIE
Meaning: Diminutive of AUDREY.

Name: AUDLEY
Meaning: From a surname that was taken from a place name meaning "EALDGYÐ's clearing" in Old English.

Name: AUDRA (2)
Meaning: Variant of AUDREY, used since the 19th century.

Name: AUDREA
Meaning: Variant of AUDREY.

Name: AUDREY
Meaning: Medieval diminutive of ÆÐELÞRYÐ. This was the name of a 7th-century saint, a princess of East Anglia who founded a monastery at Ely. It was also borne by a character in Shakespeare's comedy As You Like It (1599). At the end of the Middle Ages the name became rare due to association with the word tawdry (which was derived from St. Audrey, the name of a fair where cheap lace was sold), but it was revived in the 19th century. A famous bearer was British actress Audrey Hepburn (1929-1993).

Name: AUGUST
Usage: German, Polish, Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, Catalan, English
Meaning: German, Polish, Scandinavian and Catalan form of AUGUSTUS. This was the name of three Polish kings.... [more]

Name: AUGUSTA
Usage: Italian, Portuguese, English, German, Ancient Roman
Meaning: Feminine form of AUGUSTUS. It was introduced to Britain when King George III, a member of the German House of Hanover, gave this name to his second daughter in the 18th century.

Name: AUGUSTINE (1)
Meaning: From the Roman name Augustinus, itself derived from the Roman name AUGUSTUS. Saint Augustine of Hippo was a 5th-century Christian theologian and author from North Africa. For his contributions to Christian philosophy he is known as a Doctor of the Church. Due to his renown, the name came into general use in the Christian world. It became popular in England in the Middle Ages partly because of a second saint by this name, Augustine of Canterbury, a 6th-century Italian monk sent to England to convert the Anglo-Saxons.

Name: AURA
Meaning: From the word aura (derived from Latin, ultimately from Greek αὔρα meaning "breeze") for a distinctive atmosphere or illumination.

Name: AUREOLE
Meaning: From the English word meaning "radiant halo", ultimately derived from Latin aureolus "golden".

Name: AURORA
Usage: Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, English, German, Romanian, Finnish, Roman Mythology
Meaning: Means "dawn" in Latin. Aurora was the Roman goddess of the morning. It has occasionally been used as a given name since the Renaissance.

Name: AUSTEN
Meaning: Variant of AUSTIN.

Name: AUSTIN
Meaning: Medieval contracted form of AUGUSTINE (1). Modern use of the name is probably also partly inspired by the common surname Austin, which is of the same origin. This is also the name of a city in Texas.

Name: AUSTYN
Meaning: Variant or feminine form of AUSTIN.

Name: AUTUMN
Meaning: From the name of the season, ultimately from Latin autumnus. This name has been in general use since the 1960s.

Name: AVA (1)
Meaning: Variant of EVE. A famous bearer was the American actress Ava Gardner (1922-1990). This name became very popular throughout the English-speaking world in the early 21st century, entering the top ten for girls in the United States, the United Kingdom, Ireland, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

Name: AVAH
Meaning: Variant of AVA (1).

Name: AVALINE
Meaning: Variant of AVELINE.

Name: AVALON
Meaning: From the name of the island paradise to which King Arthur was brought after his death. The name of this island is perhaps related to Welsh afal meaning "apple", a fruit that was often linked with paradise.

Name: AVELINE
Meaning: From the Norman French form of the Germanic name Avelina, a diminutive of AVILA. The Normans introduced this name to Britain. After the Middle Ages it became rare as an English name, though it persisted in America until the 19th century.

Name: AVERIE
Meaning: Variant of AVERY.

Name: AVERILL
Meaning: From a surname that was originally derived from the feminine given name EOFORHILD.

Name: AVERY
Meaning: From a surname that was itself derived from the Norman French form of the given names ALBERICH or ALFRED.

Name: AVIANA
Meaning: Probably an elaboration of AVA (1), influenced by names such as Ariana.

Name: AVIANNA
Meaning: Variant of AVIANA.

Name: AVICE
Meaning: Variant of AVIS.

Name: AVIS
Meaning: Probably a Latinized form of the Germanic name Aveza, which was derived from the element avi, of unknown meaning, possibly "desired". The Normans introduced this name to England and it became moderately common during the Middle Ages, at which time it was associated with Latin avis "bird".

Name: AVONLEA
Meaning: Created by Lucy Maud Montgomery as the setting for her novel Anne of Green Gables (1908). She may have based the name on the Arthurian island of AVALON, though it also resembles the river name AVON and leah "woodland, clearing".

Name: AVRIL
Meaning: French form of APRIL.

Name: AXEL
Usage: Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, German, French, English
Meaning: Medieval Danish form of ABSALOM.

Name: AXL
Meaning: Variant of AXEL, used famously by musician Axl Rose (1962-).

Name: AYDAN (2)
Meaning: Variant of AIDAN.

Name: AYDEN
Meaning: Variant of AIDAN.

Name: AYLMER
Meaning: From a surname that was a variant of ELMER.

Name: AZALEA
Meaning: From the name of the flower (shrubs of the genus Rhododendron), ultimately derived from Greek ἀζαλέος (azaleos) meaning "dry".

Name: AZARIA
Meaning: Hebrew form of AZARIAH (masculine), as well as a feminine variant in the English-speaking world.

Name: AZURA
Meaning: Elaboration of AZURE.

Name: AZURE
Meaning: From the English word that means "sky blue". It is ultimately (via Old French, Latin and Arabic) from Persian لاجورد (lajvard) meaning "azure, lapis lazuli".

Name: BABETTE
Meaning: French diminutive of ELIZABETH or BARBARA.

Name: BABS
Meaning: Diminutive of BARBARA.

Name: BAILEE
Meaning: Variant of BAILEY.

Name: BAILEY
Meaning: From a surname derived from Middle English baili meaning "bailiff", originally denoting one who was a bailiff.

Name: BAKER
Meaning: From an English occupational surname derived from Old English bakere meaning "baker".

Name: BALDRIC
Meaning: Derived from the Germanic elements bald "bold, brave" and ric "ruler, mighty". The Normans introduced this name to Britain, and it was common in the Middle Ages.

Name: BALDWIN
Meaning: Means "bold friend", derived from the Germanic elements bald "bold, brave" and win "friend". In the Middle Ages this was a popular name in Flanders and among the Normans, who brought it to Britain. It was borne by one of the leaders of the First Crusade, an 11th-century nobleman from Flanders. After the crusaders conquered Jerusalem, he was crowned as the king of the Kingdom of Jerusalem.

Name: BALFOUR
Meaning: From a Scottish surname, originally from various place names, which meant "village pasture" in Gaelic.

Name: BAMBI
Meaning: Derived from Italian bambina meaning "young girl". The American novelist Marjorie Benton Cooke used it in her novel Bambi (1914). This was also the name of a male deer in a cartoon by Walt Disney, which was based on a 1923 novel by Swiss author Felix Salten.

Name: BARB
Meaning: Short form of BARBARA.

Name: BARBARA
Usage: English, Italian, French, German, Polish, Hungarian, Slovene, Croatian, Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, Late Roman
Meaning: Derived from Greek βάρβαρος (barbaros) meaning "foreign". According to legend, Saint Barbara was a young woman killed by her father Dioscorus, who was then killed by a bolt of lightning. She is the patron of architects, geologists, stonemasons and artillerymen. Because of her renown, the name came into general use in the Christian world in the Middle Ages. In England it became rare after the Protestant Reformation, but it was revived in the 19th century.

Name: BARBIE
Meaning: Diminutive of BARBARA.

Name: BARBRA
Meaning: Variant of BARBARA.

Name: BARCLAY
Meaning: From a Scottish surname that was likely derived from the English place name Berkeley, meaning "birch wood" in Old English.

Name: BARNABAS
Usage: German (Rare), English (Rare), Biblical, Biblical Latin, Biblical Greek
Meaning: Greek form of an Aramaic name. In Acts in the New Testament the byname Barnabas was given to a man named Joseph, a Jew from Cyprus who was a companion of Paul on his missionary journeys. The original Aramaic form is unattested, but it may be from בּר נביא (bar naviya') meaning "son of the prophet", though in Acts 4:36 it is claimed that the name means "son of encouragement".... [more]

Name: BARNABY
Meaning: Medieval English form of BARNABAS.

Name: BARNEY
Meaning: Diminutive of BARNABAS, BERNARD or BARNABY.

Name: BARRET
Meaning: From a surname that was a variant of BARRETT.

Name: BARRETT
Meaning: From a surname probably meaning "strife" in Middle English, originally given to a quarrelsome person.

Name: BARRIE
Meaning: Variant of BARRY.

Name: BARRY
Meaning: Anglicized form of BAIRRE. It is also sometimes used as an Anglicized form of BERACH.

Name: BART
Meaning: Short form of BARTHOLOMEW. This name is borne by a cartoon boy on the television series The Simpsons.

Name: BARTHOLOMEW
Meaning: English form of Βαρθολομαῖος (Bartholomaios), which was the Greek form of an Aramaic name meaning "son of TALMAI". In the New Testament Bartholomew is the byname of an apostle, possibly the same person as the apostle Nathanael. According to tradition he was a missionary to India before returning westward to Armenia, where he was martyred by flaying. Due to the popularity of this saint the name became common in England during the Middle Ages.

Name: BASIL (1)
Meaning: From the Greek name Βασίλειος (Basileios), which was derived from βασιλεύς (basileus) meaning "king". Saint Basil the Great was a 4th-century bishop of Caesarea and one of the fathers of the early Christian church. Due to him, the name (in various spellings) has come into general use in the Christian world, being especially popular among Eastern Christians. It was also borne by two Byzantine emperors.

Name: BAXTER
Meaning: From an occupational surname that meant "(female) baker" in Old English.

Name: BAYLEE
Meaning: Variant of BAILEY.

Name: BAZ
Meaning: Diminutive of BARRY or BASIL (1).

Name: BAZZA
Meaning: Diminutive of BARRY or BASIL (1).

Name: BEA
Meaning: Short form of BEATRIX.

Name: BEATRICE
Meaning: Italian form of BEATRIX. Beatrice Portinari (1266-1290) was the woman who was loved by the Italian poet Dante Alighieri. She serves as Dante's guide through paradise in his epic poem the Divine Comedy (1321). This is also the name of a character in Shakespeare's comedy Much Ado About Nothing (1599), in which Beatrice and Benedick are fooled into confessing their love for one another.

Name: BEATRIX
Usage: German, Hungarian, Dutch, English, Late Roman
Meaning: Probably from Viatrix, a feminine form of the Late Latin name Viator meaning "voyager, traveller". It was a common name amongst early Christians, and the spelling was altered by association with Latin beatus "blessed, happy". Viatrix or Beatrix was a 4th-century saint who was strangled to death during the persecutions of Diocletian.... [more]

Name: BEAU
Meaning: Means "beautiful" in French. It has been used as a given name since the middle of the 20th century. In Margaret Mitchell's novel Gone with the Wind (1936) this is the name of Ashley and Melanie's son.... [more]

Name: BEAUDEN
Meaning: Elaboration of French beau "beautiful", using the popular den suffix sound found in such names as Braden, Hayden and Aidan. This name has become popular in New Zealand due to rugby player Beauden Barrett (1991-).

Name: BEAUMONT
Meaning: From a French surname meaning "beautiful mountain".

Name: BEAUREGARD
Meaning: From a French surname meaning "beautiful outlook".

Name: BECCA
Meaning: Short form of REBECCA.

Name: BECCI
Meaning: Diminutive of REBECCA.

Name: BECKA
Meaning: Short form of REBECCA.

Name: BECKAH
Meaning: Short form of REBECCA.

Name: BECKETT
Meaning: From an English surname that could be derived from various sources, including from Middle English beke meaning "beak" or bekke meaning "stream, brook".

Name: BECKHAM
Meaning: From an English surname that was derived from a place name meaning "Becca's homestead" in Old English. A famous bearer of the surname is retired English soccer player David Beckham (1975-).

Name: BECKY
Meaning: Diminutive of REBECCA.

Name: BEE
Meaning: Short form of BEATRIX and other names beginning with B.

Name: BEKKI
Meaning: Diminutive of REBECCA.

Name: BELINDA
Meaning: The meaning of this name is not known for certain. The first element could be related to Italian bella "beautiful". The second element could be Germanic lind meaning "flexible, soft, tender" (and by extension "snake, serpent"). This name first arose in the 17th century, and was subsequently used by Alexander Pope in his poem The Rape of the Lock (1712).

Name: BELLA
Meaning: Short form of ISABELLA and other names ending in bella. It is also associated with the Italian word bella meaning "beautiful".

Name: BELLAMY
Meaning: From a surname derived from Old French bel ami meaning "beautiful friend".

Name: BELLE
Meaning: Short form of ISABELLA or names ending in belle. It is also associated with the French word belle meaning "beautiful". A famous bearer was Belle Starr (1848-1889), an outlaw of the American west, whose real given name was Maybelle.

Name: BEN (1)
Meaning: Short form of BENJAMIN or BENEDICT. A notable bearer was Ben Jonson (1572-1637), an English poet and playwright.

Name: BENEDICT
Meaning: From the Late Latin name Benedictus, which meant "blessed". Saint Benedict was an Italian monk who founded the Benedictines in the 6th century. After his time the name was common among Christians, being used by 16 popes. In England it did not come into use until the 12th century, at which point it became very popular. This name was also borne by the American general Benedict Arnold (1741-1801), who defected to Britain during the American Revolution.

Name: BENJ
Meaning: Short form of BENJAMIN.

Name: BENJAMIN
Usage: English, French, German, Dutch, Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, Biblical
Meaning: From the Hebrew name בִּנְיָמִין (Binyamin) meaning "son of the south" or "son of the right hand", from the roots בֵּן (ben) meaning "son" and יָמִין (yamin) meaning "right hand, south". Benjamin in the Old Testament was the twelfth and youngest son of Jacob and the founder of one of the southern tribes of the Hebrews. He was originally named בֶּן־אוֹנִי (Ben-'oni) meaning "son of my sorrow" by his mother Rachel, who died shortly after childbirth, but it was later changed by his father (see Genesis 35:18).... [more]

Name: BENJI
Meaning: Diminutive of BENJAMIN.

Name: BENJY
Meaning: Diminutive of BENJAMIN.

Name: BENNETT
Meaning: Medieval form of BENEDICT. This was the more common spelling in England until the 18th century. Modern use of the name is probably also influenced by the common surname Bennett, itself a derivative of the medieval name.

Name: BENNIE
Meaning: Diminutive of BENJAMIN or BENEDICT.

Name: BENNY
Meaning: Diminutive of BENJAMIN or BENEDICT.

Name: BENSON
Meaning: From a surname that originally meant "son of BENEDICT".

Name: BENTLEY
Meaning: From a surname that was from a place name, itself derived from Old English beonet "bent grass" and leah "woodland, clearing". Various towns in England bear this name.

Name: BENTON
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from a place name, composed of Old English beonet "bent grass" and tun "enclosure".

Name: BERENICE
Meaning: Latinized form of Βερενίκη (Berenike), the Macedonian form of the Greek name Φερενίκη (Pherenike), which meant "bringing victory" from φέρω (phero) meaning "to bring" and νίκη (nike) meaning "victory". This name was common among the Ptolemy ruling family of Egypt, a dynasty that was originally from Macedon. It occurs briefly in Acts in the New Testament (in most English Bibles it is spelled Bernice) belonging to a sister of King Herod Agrippa II. As an English name, Berenice came into use after the Protestant Reformation.

Name: BERNADETTE
Meaning: French feminine form of BERNARD. Saint Bernadette was a young woman from Lourdes in France who claimed to have seen visions of the Virgin Mary.

Name: BERNADINE
Meaning: Feminine form of BERNARD.

Name: BERNARD
Usage: English, French, Dutch, Polish, Croatian, Slovene, Czech, Ancient Germanic
Meaning: Derived from the Germanic element bern "bear" combined with hard "brave, hardy". The Normans brought it to England, where it replaced the Old English cognate Beornheard. This was the name of several saints, including Saint Bernard of Menthon who built hospices in the Swiss Alps in the 10th century, and Saint Bernard of Clairvaux, a 12th-century theologian and Doctor of the Church. Other famous bearers include the Irish playwright and essayist George Bernard Shaw (1856-1950) and the British World War II field marshal Bernard Montgomery (1887-1976).

Name: BERNETTA
Meaning: Diminutive of BERENICE.

Name: BERNICE
Meaning: Contracted form of BERENICE. It occurs briefly in Acts in the New Testament belonging to a sister of King Herod Agrippa II.

Name: BERNIE
Meaning: Diminutive of BERNARD, BERNADETTE, BERNICE, and other names beginning with Bern.

Name: BERNIECE
Meaning: Variant of BERNICE.

Name: BERNY
Meaning: Variant of BERNIE.

Name: BERRY (1)
Meaning: Variant of BARRY.

Name: BERRY (2)
Meaning: From the English word referring to the small fruit. It is ultimately derived from Old English berie. This name has only been in use since the 20th century.

Name: BERT
Meaning: Short form of ALBERT and other names containing the element bert, often derived from the Germanic element beraht meaning "bright".

Name: BERTHA
Meaning: Originally a short form of Germanic names beginning with the element beraht meaning "bright, famous". It was borne by the mother of Charlemagne in the 8th century, and it was popularized in England by the Normans. It died out as an English name after the Middle Ages, but was revived in the 19th century. The name also appears in southern Germanic legends (often spelled Perchta or Berchta) belonging to a goddess of animals and weaving.

Name: BERTIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ALBERT, HERBERT, and other names containing bert (often derived from the Germanic element beraht meaning "bright").

Name: BERTINA
Meaning: Feminine form of BERT.

Name: BERTRAM
Meaning: Means "bright raven", derived from the Germanic element beraht "bright" combined with hramn "raven". The Normans introduced this name to England. Shakespeare used it in his play All's Well That Ends Well (1603).

Name: BERTRAND
Meaning: Derived from the Germanic elements beraht meaning "bright" and rand meaning "rim (of a shield)". From an early date it has been confused with BERTRAM and the two names have merged to some degree. A famous bearer was English philosopher Bertrand Russell (1872-1970).

Name: BERYL
Meaning: From the English word for the clear or pale green precious stone, ultimately deriving from Sanskrit. As a given name, it first came into use in the 19th century.

Name: BESS
Meaning: Diminutive of ELIZABETH.

Name: BESSIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ELIZABETH.

Name: BETH
Meaning: Short form of ELIZABETH, or sometimes BETHANY.

Name: BETHANIE
Meaning: Variant of BETHANY.

Name: BETHANY
Meaning: From the name of a biblical town, Βηθανία (Bethania) in Greek, which is probably of Aramaic or Hebrew origin, possibly meaning "house of affliction" or "house of figs". In the New Testament the town of Bethany is the home of Lazarus and his sisters Mary and Martha. It has been in use as a rare given name in the English-speaking world since the 19th century, used primarily by Catholics in honour of Mary of Bethany. In America it became moderately common after the 1950s.

Name: BETHEL
Meaning: From an Old Testament place name meaning "house of God" in Hebrew. This was a town north of Jerusalem, where Jacob saw his vision of the stairway. It is occasionally used as a given name.

Name: BETHNEY
Meaning: Variant of BETHANY.

Name: BETONY
Meaning: From the name of the minty medicinal herb.

Name: BETSY
Meaning: Diminutive of ELIZABETH.

Name: BETTE
Meaning: Diminutive of ELIZABETH. A famous bearer was American actress Bette Davis (1908-1989).

Name: BETTIE
Meaning: Diminutive of ELIZABETH.

Name: BETTY
Meaning: Diminutive of ELIZABETH.

Name: BETTYE
Meaning: Variant of BETTY.

Name: BEULAH
Meaning: Means "married" in Hebrew. The name is used in the Old Testament to refer to the land of Israel (Isaiah 62:4). As an English given name, Beulah has been used since the Protestant Reformation.

Name: BEV
Meaning: Short form of BEVERLY.

Name: BEVERLEY
Meaning: Variant of BEVERLY.

Name: BEVERLY
Meaning: From a surname that was originally derived from the name of an English city, itself meaning "beaver stream" in Old English. It came into use as a masculine given name in the 19th century, and it became common as an American feminine name after the publication of George Barr McCutcheon's 1904 novel Beverly of Graustark.

Name: BEVIS
Meaning: From an English surname that is possibly derived from the name of the French town Beauvais.

Name: BIDDY
Meaning: Diminutive of BRIDGET.

Name: BIFF
Meaning: From a nickname that was based on the English word biff, which means "punch, hit, strike".

Name: BILL
Meaning: Short form of WILLIAM. This spelling was first used in the 19th century. The change in the initial consonant may have been influenced by an earlier Irish pronunciation of the name. Famous bearers include basketball player Bill Russell (1934-), comedian Bill Cosby (1937-), American president Bill Clinton (1946-), and Microsoft founder Bill Gates (1955-).

Name: BILLIE
Meaning: Diminutive of BILL. It is also used as a feminine form of WILLIAM.

Name: BILLY
Meaning: Diminutive of BILL. A notable bearer was the American outlaw Billy the Kid (1859-1881), whose real name was William H. Bonney.

Name: BINDY
Meaning: Diminutive of BELINDA.

Name: BIRDIE
Meaning: Diminutive of BERTHA, BERNICE or other names with a similar sound, or sometimes simply from the English word bird.

Name: BISHOP
Meaning: Either from the English occupational surname, or else directly from the English word. It is ultimately derived from Greek ἐπίσκοπος (episkopos) meaning "overseer".

Name: BLAINE
Meaning: From a Scottish surname that was derived from the given name Bláán, which meant "yellow" in Gaelic. Saint Bláán was a 6th-century missionary to the Picts.

Name: BLAIR
Meaning: From a Scottish surname that is derived from Gaelic blár meaning "plain, field, battlefield".

Name: BLAKE
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from Old English blæc "black" or blac "pale". A famous bearer of the surname was the poet and artist William Blake (1757-1827).

Name: BLAKELY
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from Old English blæc "black" and leah "woodland clearing".

Name: BLANCH
Meaning: Variant of BLANCHE.

Name: BLANCHE
Meaning: From a medieval French nickname meaning "white, fair". This name and its cognates in other languages are ultimately derived from the Germanic word blanc. An early bearer was the 12th-century Blanca of Navarre, the wife of Sancho III of Castile. Her granddaughter of the same name married Louis VIII of France, with the result that the name became more common in France.

Name: BLAZE
Meaning: Modern variant of BLAISE influenced by the English word blaze.

Name: BLONDIE
Meaning: From a nickname for a person with blond hair. This is the name of the title character in a comic strip by Chic Young.

Name: BLOSSOM
Meaning: From the English word blossom, ultimately from Old English blóstm. It came into use as a rare given name in the 19th century.

Name: BLYTHE
Meaning: From a surname meaning "cheerful" in Old English.

Name: BOB
Meaning: Short form of ROBERT. It arose later than Dob, Hob and Nob, which were medieval rhyming nicknames of Robert. It was borne by the character Bob Cratchit in Charles Dickens' novel A Christmas Carol (1843). Other famous bearers include American folk musician Bob Dylan (1941-) and Jamaican reggae musician Bob Marley (1945-1981).

Name: BOBBI
Meaning: Diminutive of ROBERTA or BARBARA.

Name: BOBBIE
Meaning: Variant of BOBBY. As a feminine name it can be a diminutive of ROBERTA or BARBARA.

Name: BOBBY
Meaning: Diminutive of BOB. Hockey greats Bobby Hull (1939-) and Bobby Orr (1948-) have borne this name.

Name: BODHI
Meaning: From a term referring to enlightenment in Buddhism, derived from Sanskrit बोधि (bodhi).

Name: BONIFACE
Meaning: From the Late Latin name Bonifatius, which meant "good fate" from bonum "good" and fatum "fate". This was the name of nine popes and also several saints, including an 8th-century Anglo-Saxon missionary to Germany (originally named Winfrid) who is now regarded as the patron saint of that country. It came into use in England during the Middle Ages, but became rare after the Protestant Reformation.

Name: BONITA
Meaning: Means "pretty" in Spanish, ultimately from Latin bonus "good". It has been used as a name in the English-speaking world since the beginning of the 20th century.

Name: BONNIE
Meaning: Means "pretty" from the Scottish word bonnie, which was itself derived from Middle French bon "good". It has been in use as an American given name since the 19th century, and it became especially popular after the movie Gone with the Wind (1939), in which it was the nickname of Scarlett's daughter.

Name: BOOKER
Meaning: From an English occupational surname meaning "maker of books". A famous bearer was Booker T. Washington (1856-1915), an African-American leader.

Name: BOONE
Meaning: From an English surname that was either derived from Old French bon meaning "good" or from the name of the town of Bohon, France.

Name: BOYCE
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from Old French bois "wood".

Name: BOYD
Meaning: From a Scottish surname that was possibly derived from the name of the island of Bute.

Name: BRAD
Meaning: Short form of BRADLEY, BRADFORD, and other names beginning with Brad. A famous bearer is American actor Brad Pitt (1963-).

Name: BRADEN
Meaning: From an Irish surname that was derived from Ó Bradáin meaning "descendant of BRADÁN".

Name: BRADFORD
Meaning: From a surname that originally came from a place name that meant "broad ford" in Old English.

Name: BRADLEY
Meaning: From a surname that originally came from a place name meaning "broad clearing" in Old English. A famous bearer of the surname was the World War II American general Omar Bradley (1893-1981).

Name: BRADY
Meaning: From an Irish surname that was derived from Ó Brádaigh meaning "descendant of BRÁDACH".

Name: BRAEDEN
Meaning: Variant of BRADEN.

Name: BRAELYN
Meaning: A recently created name, formed using the popular name suffix lyn.

Name: BRAELYNN
Meaning: Variant of BRAELYN.

Name: BRAIDEN
Meaning: Variant of BRADEN.

Name: BRAIDY
Meaning: Variant of BRADY.

Name: BRAITH
Meaning: Meaning uncertain, perhaps from Welsh brith, braith meaning "speckled".

Name: BRAM
Meaning: Short form of ABRAHAM. This name was borne by Bram Stoker (1847-1912), the Irish author who wrote Dracula.

Name: BRAND
Meaning: From a surname, a variant of BRANT.

Name: BRANDA
Meaning: Perhaps a variant of BRANDY or a feminine form of BRAND.

Name: BRANDE
Meaning: Variant of BRANDY.

Name: BRANDEE
Meaning: Variant of BRANDY.

Name: BRANDEN
Meaning: Variant of BRANDON.

Name: BRANDI
Meaning: Variant of BRANDY.

Name: BRANDIE
Meaning: Variant of BRANDY.

Name: BRANDON
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from a place name meaning "hill covered with broom" in Old English. It is sometimes also used as a variant of BRENDAN.

Name: BRANDT
Meaning: From a surname, a variant of BRANT.

Name: BRANDY
Meaning: From the English word brandy for the alcoholic drink. It is ultimately from Dutch brandewijn "burnt wine". It has been in use as a given name since the 1960s.

Name: BRANNON
Meaning: From an Irish surname derived from Mac Branain, which means "descendant of BRAN (1)".

Name: BRANSON
Meaning: From an English surname that meant "son of BRANDR".

Name: BRANT
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from the Old Norse given name BRANDR. This is also the name for a variety of wild geese.

Name: BRANTLEY
Meaning: From a surname, an Americanized form of the German surname Brändle, ultimately from Old High German brant "fire".

Name: BRAXTON
Meaning: From an English surname that was originally derived from a place name meaning "Bracca's town" in Old English.

Name: BRAYDEN
Meaning: Variant of BRADEN.

Name: BRAYLEN
Meaning: Variant of BRAYLON.

Name: BRAYLON
Meaning: An invented name, using the same sounds found in names such as Braden and Jalen.

Name: BREANA
Meaning: Variant of BRIANA.

Name: BREANN
Meaning: Feminine form of BRIAN.

Name: BREANNA
Meaning: Variant of BRIANA.

Name: BREANNE
Meaning: Feminine form of BRIAN.

Name: BREE
Meaning: Anglicized form of BRÍGH. It can also be a short form of BRIANNA, GABRIELLA or other names containing bri.

Name: BRENDA
Meaning: Possibly a feminine form of the Old Norse name Brandr, meaning "sword", which was brought to Britain in the Middle Ages. This name is sometimes used as a feminine form of BRENDAN.

Name: BRENDAN
Meaning: From Brendanus, the Latinized form of the Irish name Bréanainn, which was derived from a Welsh word meaning "prince". Saint Brendan was a 6th-century Irish abbot who, according to legend, crossed the Atlantic and reached North America with 17 other monks.

Name: BRENDEN
Meaning: Variant of BRENDAN.

Name: BRENDON
Meaning: Variant of BRENDAN.

Name: BRENNA
Meaning: Possibly a variant of BRENDA or a feminine form of BRENNAN.

Name: BRENNAN
Meaning: From an Irish surname derived from Ó Braonáin meaning "descendant of Braonán". Braonán is a byname meaning "rain, moisture, drop" (with a diminutive suffix).

Name: BRENT
Meaning: From an English surname, originally taken from various place names, perhaps derived from a Celtic word meaning "hill".

Name: BRENTON
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from an English place name meaning "Bryni's town". Bryni was Old English name meaning "fire".

Name: BRET
Meaning: Variant of BRETT.

Name: BRETT
Meaning: From a Middle English surname meaning "a Breton", referring to an inhabitant of Brittany. A famous bearer is the American football quarterback Brett Favre (1969-).

Name: BRIA
Meaning: Short form of BRIANNA, GABRIELLA or other names containing bri.

Name: BRIAN
Meaning: The meaning of this name is not known for certain but it is possibly related to the old Celtic element bre meaning "hill", or by extension "high, noble". It was borne by the semi-legendary Irish king Brian Boru, who thwarted Viking attempts to conquer Ireland in the 11th century. He was slain in the Battle of Clontarf, though his forces were decisively victorious. The name was common in Ireland before his time, and even more so afterwards. It came into use in England in the Middle Ages, introduced by Breton settlers. It subsequently became rare, but was revived in the 20th century.

Name: BRIANA
Meaning: Feminine form of BRIAN. This name was used by Edmund Spenser in The Faerie Queene (1590). The name was not commonly used until the 1970s, when it rapidly became popular in the United States.

Name: BRIANNA
Meaning: Variant of BRIANA.

Name: BRIANNE
Meaning: Feminine form of BRIAN.

Name: BRIAR
Meaning: From the English word for the thorny plant.

Name: BRICE
Meaning: From the name Bricius, which was probably a Latinized form of a Gaulish name meaning "speckled". This was the name of a 5th-century saint, a disciple of Saint Martin of Tours.

Name: BRIDGER
Meaning: From an English surname that originally indicated a person who lived near or worked on a bridge.

Name: BRIDGET
Meaning: Anglicized form of the Irish name Brighid meaning "exalted one". In Irish mythology this was the name of the goddess of fire, poetry and wisdom, the daughter of the god Dagda. In the 5th century it was borne by Saint Brigid, the founder of a monastery at Kildare and a patron saint of Ireland. Because of the saint, the name was considered sacred in Ireland, and it did not come into general use there until the 17th century. In the form Birgitta this name has been common in Scandinavia, made popular by the 14th-century Saint Birgitta of Sweden, patron saint of Europe.

Name: BRIDGETTE
Meaning: Variant of BRIDGET.

Name: BRIELLA
Meaning: Short form of GABRIELLA.

Name: BRIELLE
Meaning: Short form of GABRIELLE. This is also the name of towns in the Netherlands and New Jersey, though their names derive from a different source.

Name: BRIGHAM
Meaning: From a surname that was originally derived from place names meaning "bridge settlement" in Old English.

Name: BRINLEY
Meaning: From an English surname that was taken from the name of a town meaning "burned clearing" in Old English.

Name: BRION
Meaning: Variant of BRIAN.

Name: BRIONY
Meaning: Variant of BRYONY.

Name: BRISCOE
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from a place name meaning "birch wood" in Old Norse.

Name: BRISTOL
Meaning: From the name of the city in southwest England that means "the site of the bridge".

Name: BRITANNIA
Meaning: From the Latin name of the island of Britain, in occasional use as an English given name since the 18th century. This is also the name of the Roman female personification of Britain pictured on some British coins.

Name: BRITNEY
Meaning: Variant of BRITTANY.

Name: BRITTANI
Meaning: Variant of BRITTANY.

Name: BRITTANIA
Meaning: Variant of BRITANNIA.

Name: BRITTANY
Meaning: From the name of the region in the northwest of France, called in French Bretagne. It was named for the Britons who settled there after the fall of the Western Roman Empire and the invasions of the Anglo-Saxons.... [more]

Name: BRITTNEY
Meaning: Variant of BRITTANY.

Name: BRITTNY
Meaning: Variant of BRITTANY.

Name: BRITTON
Meaning: Derived from a Middle English surname meaning "a Briton" (a Celt of England) or "a Breton" (an inhabitant of Brittany).

Name: BROCK
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from Old English brocc meaning "badger".

Name: BRODIE
Meaning: Variant of BRODY.

Name: BRODY
Meaning: From a surname that was originally derived from a place in Moray, Scotland. It probably means "ditch, mire" in Gaelic.

Name: BRONTE
Meaning: From a surname, an Anglicized form of Irish Ó Proinntigh meaning "descendant of Proinnteach". The given name Proinnteach meant "bestower" in Gaelic. The Brontë sisters - Charlotte, Emily, and Anne - were 19th-century English novelists. Their father changed the spelling of the family surname from Brunty to Brontë, possibly to make it coincide with Greek βροντή meaning "thunder".

Name: BROOK
Meaning: From an English surname that denoted one who lived near a brook.

Name: BROOKE
Meaning: Variant of BROOK. The name came into use in the 1950s, probably influenced by American socialite Brooke Astor (1902-2007). It was further popularized by actress Brooke Shields (1965-).

Name: BROOKLYN
Meaning: From the name of a borough of New York City, originally named after the Dutch town of Breukelen, itself meaning either "broken land" (from Dutch breuk) or "marsh land" (from Dutch broek). It can also be viewed as a combination of BROOK and the popular name suffix lyn. It is considered a feminine name in the United States, but is more common as a masculine name in the United Kingdom.

Name: BROOKLYNN
Meaning: Variant of BROOKLYN.

Name: BROOKS
Meaning: From an English surname, a variant of BROOK.

Name: BRUCE
Meaning: From a Scottish surname, of Norman origin, which probably originally referred to the town of Brix in France. The surname was borne by Robert the Bruce, a Scottish hero of the 14th century who achieved independence from England and became the king of Scotland. It has been in use as a given name in the English-speaking world since the 19th century. A notable bearer is the American musician Bruce Springsteen (1949-).

Name: BRYAN
Meaning: Variant of BRIAN.

Name: BRYANA
Meaning: Variant of BRIANA.

Name: BRYANNA
Meaning: Variant of BRIANA.

Name: BRYANNE
Meaning: Feminine form of BRIAN.

Name: BRYANT
Meaning: From a surname that was derived from the given name BRIAN.

Name: BRYCE
Meaning: Variant of BRICE.

Name: BRYCEN
Meaning: Variant of BRYSON.

Name: BRYN
Meaning: Means "hill, mound" in Welsh. It is now used as a feminine name as well.

Name: BRYNLEE
Meaning: Combination of BRYN and the popular name suffix lee. It could also be considered a variant of BRINLEY.

Name: BRYNN
Meaning: Feminine variant of BRYN.

Name: BRYNNE
Meaning: Feminine variant of BRYN.

Name: BRYON
Meaning: Variant of BRIAN.

Name: BRYONY
Meaning: From the name of a type of Eurasian vine, formerly used as medicine. It ultimately derives from Greek βρύω (bryo) meaning "to swell".

Name: BRYSON
Meaning: From an English surname meaning "son of BRICE".

Name: BUCK
Meaning: From an English nickname meaning simply "buck, male deer", ultimately from Old English bucc.

Name: BUD
Meaning: Short form of BUDDY.

Name: BUDDY
Meaning: From the English word meaning "friend". It probably originated as a nursery form of the word brother.

Name: BUFFY
